New Site Who This?

February 22, 2026 2 min read
meta

I’ve been meaning to start a blog for a while, and it felt like a good excuse to redesign my site.

Historically, this has been a straightforward portfolio—a place to prove that I can, in fact, code and work with modern web frameworks. But recently I’ve been increasingly inspired by the indie web movement and the care individuals put into their personal sites. There’s a lot I’d still like to change about the current iteration, but that’s okay. I tend to see most things in life as a process of becoming. And I think that’s beautiful.

Completed projects are great (and impressive), but the problem-solving phase is where I have the most fun.

Through this blog, I hope to share and develop ideas around the things I find interesting and inspiring: AI (done right), philosophy, bikes, computers, and the great outdoors. Those who know me personally know that I like to geek out on the details and sit with the ambiguous spaces between right and wrong, known and unknown. My primary goal is simple: to do that which promotes life.

We’re living through a time that feels both scary and electric. I’m interested in exploring what this moment means—trying to understand it—but also in building and supporting systems that help people for the sake of helping people as we move through this transition.

I’m skeptical of anyone who claims to predict the future. Still, it feels clear that large-scale change is coming, and we’ll need to adapt. Lately I’ve been thinking about the Industrial Revolution and the parallels to our own moment. Some of the photographs that first drew me into photography were taken during that era. They documented real horrors—but they also served as evidence, as leverage to fight for better standards of living.

Today, seeing is no longer believing. Images have lost some of their integrity. Realistically, nothing can fully prepare us for what’s coming. That’s unsettling—but it’s also exciting.

That isn’t meant to sound defeatist. If anything, it’s the opposite.

We may not know what’s ahead, but we still have agency in how we respond. And I believe we owe it to each other to do our best.

Owen Kobasz © 2026
